# Research {style="text-align: center;"}

Machine Learning Technology Complements Auditor Expertise

## Genesis

::: incremental
-   Grant from University of Arkansas

-   Horse race between models

-   Comparison to auditors

-   Combining ML and auditor expertise
:::

## Overview

::: incremental
-   Incorporating machine learning (ML) into audit procedures

-   Potential threat to auditor jobs and the need to evaluate the efficacy of ML in complementing auditor expertise

-   Bank failure prediction is a relevant and complex task for auditors
:::

## Methodology

::: incremental
-   ML techniques used for anomaly detection in predicting bank failure

    ::: incremental
    -   [Isolation Forest]

    -   [One-Class Support Vector Machines]
    :::

-   Publicly available data and bank call reports

-   Comparison of ML models to auditor-issued Going Concern Opinions (GCOs)
:::

## Results

::: incremental
-   ML models compared to GCOs in predicting bank failure show higher Type I error rates of ML models
    -   [Table 4a] - Crisis

    -   [Table 5a] - Post Crisis
-   Hybrid approach that combines ML models with GCOs in capturing the same number of bank failures while reducing Type I errors
    -   [Table 6a] - Crisis and Post Crisis
-   Implementability
    -   [Table 7a] - Full Sample
:::

## Implications/Conclusion

::: incremental
-   For auditors, audit firms, and regulators

-   Importance of balancing the benefits and limitations of ML in informing audit judgments

-   Need for further research and exploration of ML applications in auditing

-   Encourage continued dialogue and collaboration between auditors, ML experts, and regulators to improve audit quality and effectiveness.

-   THANK YOU üëè
:::

# Isolation Forest

::: incremental
-   It works by constructing decision trees and isolating instances that are easy to separate from the rest of the data.

-   The instances that require fewer splits to isolate are considered more anomalous.

-   Isolation Forest is efficient and effective for high-dimensional datasets and can handle large amounts of data.
:::

# One-Class Support Vector Machines

::: incremental
-   It is trained on a dataset that contains only normal data.

-   The goal is to identify new data points that are not normal.

-   It is based on the idea of finding a hyperplane that separates the normal data from everything else.
:::
